newsitem.title: UK: Lucas to dominate LucasVarity management.
newsitem.headline: Lucas to dominate LucasVarity management.

text.p: Anglo-U.S. motor components manufacturer LucasVarity, created by the merger of Lucas Industries and Varity Corp, said on Wednesday its management would be derived chiefly from Lucas executives.
"There will be 100 top jobs at LucasVarity and more will be going to Lucas management than Varity," Sarah Ward, corporate communications manager at Lucas, told Reuters in a telephone interview.
Ward declined to give details and said Lucas was scheduled to release a statement on the changes later in the day.
Ward said a report in Wednesday's edition of the Financial Times, which said 50 managers would lose their jobs as part of a 115 million sterling ($180 million) cost-cutting drive, was overstated.
"One hundred and fifty jobs will go into 100 but that does not necessarily mean redundancies...there may be other opportunities," she said.
But she said the 450 job losses mentioned in the FT were a "fair figure". The combined group employs around 56,000 workers. She declined to say whether more job losses were on the cards.
Ward confirmed the sales forecast in the FT report, which said LucasVarity was seeking to double annual sales to 10 billion stg by 2005.

Jonathan Storey, director of European Automotive Research, said the sales forecast was feasible and called the planned job cuts a bold and rapid move which could help generate the economies of scale needed to compete internationally.
"We can expect that sort of growth rate from developing markets and the target sounds feasible," he said, adding however that the potential for short-term growth in the Far East was often overstated.
"We won't see big returns in five years, probably looking at a minimum of ten...The vehicles being built there are low cost, utilitarian and low margin," he said. ($ = 0.638 British Pounds Sterling)
